subject: QS-Up and QS-Nu: 2 proposals for a new QS keyboard mapping (revision 2)
msgSnippet: This is a revision of the QS-Nu proposal. The only changes from the previous version are: QS Number QS-Nu 21 G alt-23	N 15	C alt-36	c 10	V 39	v For
messageBody:
This is a revision of the QS-Nu proposal. The only changes from the
previous version are:

QS Number QS-Nu
21 G
alt-23 N
15 C
alt-36 c
10 V
39 v

For completeness, here again is QS-Up, followed by the revised QS-Nu.

QS-Up: a proposed update of the Jerome font keyboard assignments for
the Quickscript Alphabet

QS number Revised name QS-Up
1 Pipe p
2 Bob b
3 Tut t
4 Deed d
5 Kick k
6 Gig g
7 Thoth T
8 Thither D *
9 Fife f
10 Valve v
11 Sis s
12 Zoos z
13 Shush S
14 Zhivago Z
15 Church c
16 Judge J
17 Yo-yo j
18 Win-win w
19 Ha-ha h
20 Whitewheat W *
21 Inkling N
22 Mime m
23 Nun n
24 Loll l
25 Roar r
26 If i
27 Eat I
28 Ed e
29 Age E
30 Ash A
31 Ice F
32 Ah y
33 Awl Y
34 On o
35 Oil q
36 Ado a
37 Out Q
38 Oak O
39 Wool V *
40 Ooze U *
41 Loch K *
42 Llan L *
43 Ax X *
44 Exam x *

Alternate letters

23 Noon M *
36 Up u

Punctuation

name dot ` *
left bracket (
right bracket )

All changes from the Jerome assignments are indicated with a *. This
proposal takes a minimalist approach, only fixing the assignments that
the author believes are most in need of an update. Letter #8 is
changed to the X-SAMPA value D due to popular demand. Letter #17 is
left alone because assigning it to y or Y triggers too many other
changes. (The QS-Nu proposal below does make this change.) Letter #20
is assigned to W for clarity. Letter #40 is assigned to U for phonetic
value, while #39 is assigned to V for visual similarity. Letter #43 is
assigned to upper-case X because it represents the tall letters {ks},
while #44 is assigned to lower-case x because it represents the deep
letters {gz}. The assignments for #41 to K and #42 to L are made for a
sound or name association. There remains no good assignment for Noon,
the alternate for #23, so M is chosen arbitrarily. At least it can be
noted that both M and {q} are bilaterally symmetric.


QS-Nu: a proposed plain-text format for the Quickscript Alphabet

QS number Revised name QS-Nu
1 Pipe p
2 Bob b
3 Tut t
4 Deed d
5 Kick k
6 Gig g
7 Thoth T
8 Thither D *
9 Fife f
10 Valve V *
11 Sis s
12 Zoos z
13 Shush S
14 Zhivago Z
15 Church C *
16 Judge j *
17 Yo-yo Y *
18 Win-win w
19 Ha-ha h
20 Whitewheat W *
21 Inkling G *
22 Mime m
23 Nun n
24 Loll l
25 Roar r
26 If i
27 Eat E *
28 Ed e *
29 Age A *
30 Ash a *
31 Ice I *
32 Ah y
33 Awl q *
34 On o
35 Oil Q *
36 Ado u *
37 Out P *
38 Oak O
39 Wool v *
40 Ooze U *
41 Loch K *
42 Llan L *
43 Ax X *
44 Exam x *

Alternate letters

23 Noon N *
36 Up c *

Punctuation

name dot ` *
left bracket (
right bracket )

Changes from the Jerome assignments are again indicated with *. This
proposal is more extensive than QS-Up, especially for the vowels.
Changes that were part of the QS-Up proposal are not explained again.
Letter #17 is assigned to Y for its phonetic value, and not to
lower-case y because that is needed for a vowel assignment. Letters
#28, #30 and #36 are assigned to common lower-case representations.
Letters #27, #29 and #31 are assigned based on the pronunciation of
the Roman letters. Letter #32 retains its assignment to y because of
visual similarity to the long stroke of the y. Letter #33 is assigned
to q because of visual similarity to the tail of the q. Letters #35,
#37 and the alternate for #36 are assigned due to a perceived visual
similarity. Vowels that are traditionally labeled short and long are
represented in this mapping by lower and upper case letters
respectively (in most cases). Note that letters #29, #31, #35 and #37
all contain a loop structure and are represented by upper case
letters, providing a memory aid.

Many of the ideas in QS-Nu are taken directly from previous proposals,
especially Peter Guinness's proposal. Thanks, Peter.

Revision 2 (2007/12/20):

The assignment for letter #21 has been changed to G, one of the
letters used in traditional spelling for this phoneme. This allows the
assignment of N to the alternate for #23, a clear improvement. The
assignments for letter #15 and the alternate letter for #36 have been
swapped. The assignments for letters #10 and #39 have been swapped.
With these changes, all vowels traditionally labeled short and long
are now represented by lower case and upper case letters respectively.
Since letter #15 is tall and letter #10 is deep, upper case Roman
letters are appropriate.

The idea for the assignments for #21 and the alternate for #23 is from
Benct Philip Jonsson's proposals. Thanks, Benct.

Ted
